questionList.questionText: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, who is concerned about his weight.  The mother says that he "spends too much time in front of his computer."  She has tried to engage him in athletic activities without success.  The patient has no comorbid conditions and takes no medications.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  BMI is 31.4 kg/m2.  The mother states that she came across a recruitment announcement for a study on treatment options for adolescents with overweight.  To participate in the study, the adolescents must be age >12, in relatively good health, and have a BMI ≥84th percentile and ≤95th percentile for age and sex.  Individuals with BMI <84th or >95th percentile for age and sex are not eligible.  According to population data, the distribution of BMI in 17-year-old boys is approximately normally distributed with a mean BMI of 25.0 kg/m2 and a standard deviation of 3.2 kg/m2.  Based on this information, which of the following statements is correct about the patient's eligibility to participate in the study?
questionList.explanationText:
A normal distribution is a symmetric, bell-shaped distribution with a fixed percentage of observations lying within a certain distance of the mean.  This distance is called the standard deviation (SD), and it represents the degree of dispersion of the data from the mean.  A percentile is the value in a normal distribution that has a specific percentage of observations below it (ie, area under the curve to the left of the specific value).

The 68-95-99.7 rule for a normal distribution can be used to identify the percentiles that correspond to values that are 1, 2, or 3 SDs from the mean.  In this example, given that the BMI in 17-year-old boys is approximately normally distributed with a mean of 25.0 kg/m2 and SD of 3.2 kg/m2:

  • 68% of BMIs of 17-year-old boys lie within 1 SD (25.0 ± 3.2 = 21.8-28.2 kg/m2), with 32% (100% − 68%) outside that range (16% below 21.8 kg/m2 and 16% above 28.2 kg/m2 because the normal distribution is symmetric around the mean).
  • 95% of BMIs lie within 2 SDs (25.0 ± 2 × 3.2 = 18.6-31.4 kg/m2), with 5% outside that range (2.5% below 18.6 kg/m2 and 2.5% above 31.4 kg/m2).
  • 99.7% of BMIs lie within 3 SDs (25.0 ± 3 × 3.2 = 15.4-34.6 kg/m2), with 0.15% below 15.4 kg/m2 and 0.15% above 34.6 kg/m2.

The BMI of a 17-year-old boy at 31.4 kg/m2 is 2 SDs above the mean BMI (given that 25.0 + 2 × 3.2 = 31.4).  A value at 2 SDs above the mean is at the 97th percentile, not the 95th percentile.  This is a corollary from the 68-95-99.7 rule:

  • 95% of the values are between 18.6 kg/m2 and 31.4 kg/m2, and

  • 2.5% of the values are below 18.6 kg/m2.

Therefore, 95% + 2.5% = 97.5% of BMIs must lie below 31.4 kg/m2 (so this patient with a BMI of 31.4 kg/m2 is at exactly the 97.5th percentile of the distribution) (Choices B and D).  Therefore, the patient is ineligible to participate because his BMI is >95th percentile.

(Choice A)  The patient's BMI is exactly 2 SDs above the mean, but this corresponds to the 97.5th percentile, not the 95th percentile; the 68-95-99.7 rule only means that 95% of values are within 2 SDs of the mean.

Educational objective:
A percentile is the value in a normal distribution that has a specified percentage of observations below it (ie, area under the curve to the left of the specific value).  The 68-95-99.7 rule can be used to identify the percentiles that correspond to values that are 1, 2, or 3 standard deviations from the mean.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Normal distribution

answerChoiceList.choice: Eligible to participate given that his BMI is ≤95th percentile
Ineligible to participate given that his BMI is <84th percentile
Ineligible to participate given that his BMI is >95th percentile
Not enough information to evaluate the patient's BMI percentile

questionList.questionText: A pediatrician working in a country in Southeast Asia wants to conduct a longitudinal study to describe health outcomes in neonates born with low birth weight (<5.8 lb).  The study will require at least 50 neonates born with low birth weight.  Birth weights in this country are approximately normally distributed with a mean of 6.2 lb and a standard deviation of 0.4 lb.  The pediatrician will randomly select 200 medical charts from the neonatal department at the city hospital.  Which of the following is closest to the expected number of neonates born with low birth weight in this sample?
questionList.explanationText:
A normal distribution is a symmetric, bell-shaped distribution with a fixed percentage of observations lying within a certain distance of the mean.  This distance is called the standard deviation (SD), and it represents the degree of dispersion of the data from the mean.

The 68-95-99.7 rule for normal (or approximately normal) distributions states that 68% of all observations lie within 1 SD of the mean, that 95% of all observations lie within 2 SDs of the mean, and that 99.7% of all observations lie within 3 SDs of the mean.

In the example, the birth weights in this country are approximately normally distributed with a mean of 6.2 lb and SD of 0.4 lb.  Based on the 68-95-99.7 rule:

  • 68% of birth weights lie within 1 SD:  6.2 ± 0.4 = 5.8-6.6; and 32% (= 100% − 68%) of birth weights lie outside that range, with 16% (= 32%/2) below 5.8 and 16% above 6.6 (because the normal distribution is symmetric around the mean)

  • 95% of birth weights lie within 2 SDs:  6.2 ± (2 × 0.4) = 5.4-7.0, with 2.5% (= 5%/2) below 5.4 and 2.5% above 7.0

  • 99.7% of birth weights lie within 3 SDs:  6.2 ± (3 × 0.4) = 5.0-7.4, with 0.15% below 5.0 and 0.15% above 7.4

A birth weight of 5.8 lb is exactly at 1 SD below the mean, so neonates born with low birth weight (ie, <5.8 lb) are more than 1 SD below the mean birth weight.  This indicates that 16% of birth weights lie below 5.8 lb (are considered low birth weight).  Given a sample of 200 neonates, the expected number of neonates born with low birth weight is therefore 200 × 0.16 = 32 (Choices A, C, D, and E).  The pediatrician will have to sample a greater number of medical charts to identify at least 50 neonates born with low birth weight needed for the study.

Educational objective:
In a normal distribution, 68% of all values are within 1 standard deviation (SD) from the mean; 95% of all values are within 2 SDs from the mean; and 99.7% of all values are within 3 SDs from the mean.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Normal distribution

answerChoiceList.choice: There is not enough information given

questionList.questionText:
A gynecologic oncology research institute isolates a potential tumor marker for endometrial cancer.  A large multicenter study is then performed to evaluate serum levels of the tumor marker in women with and without endometrial cancer.  The following curves are generated using the results of the study.

Clinical researchers decide to use the tumor antigen to develop a confirmatory test for patients with suspected endometrial cancer.  During preliminary design of the test, the cutoff point for positive/negative results is set at point A.  If the cutoff point is moved from A to B (to the right of point A), the specificity of the test will change in which of the following ways?
questionList.explanationText:
Important parameters of diagnostic tests include the following:

  • True positive (TP) - A patient with a positive test result who actually has the disease.
  • False positive (FP) - A patient with a positive test result who actually does not have the disease.
  • True negative (TN) - A patient with a negative test result who actually does not have the disease.
  • False negative (FN) - A patient with a negative test result who actually has the disease.
  • Sensitivity - The number of patients correctly testing positive for a disease divided by the total number of patients with the disease (TP / [TP + FN]).  High sensitivity means that negative results are less likely to be FNs and more likely to be TNs; thus, a negative result is better able to rule out the disease (SnOut).  Because tests with high sensitivity will correctly identify most of the patients with the disease, sensitivity is very important for screening tests (which need to minimize FNs).
  • Specificity - The number of patients correctly testing negative for a disease divided by the total number of patients without the disease (TN / [TN + FP]).  High specificity means that positive results are less likely to be FPs and more likely to be TPs; thus, a positive result is better able to rule in the disease (SpIn).  Because tests with high specificity will correctly identify most of the patients without the disease, specificity is very important for confirmatory tests (which need to minimize FPs).

In this example, moving the cutoff point from A to B will cause more patients without the disease to test negative (fewer FPs), increasing the specificity of the test.  However, as a consequence, more patients with the disease will also test negative (more FNs), resulting in decreased sensitivity.  Conversely, moving the cutoff point in the other direction (eg, B to A) will increase the number of FPs and decrease the number of FNs, decreasing specificity while increasing sensitivity.

Educational objective:
Changing the cutoff point of a quantitative diagnostic test will inversely affect its sensitivity and specificity.  Typically, raising the cutoff value will increase specificity (fewer false positives) and decrease sensitivity (more false negatives).  Screening tests need high sensitivity; confirmatory tests need high specificity.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity and specificity

questionList.questionText:
An interdisciplinary group of researchers conducted a study to estimate and compare the incidence of adverse events (AEs), defined as injuries caused by medical management, in patients hospitalized at 2 large university hospitals, Hospital A and Hospital B.  Researchers reviewed medical records randomly selected from each hospital.  An excerpt of study results is as follows:

Hospital AHospital Bp-value
Percentage of AEs (overall)3.6%5.1%0.003
Percentage of AEs due to negligence27.7%28.1%0.52

Which of the following most likely represents the 95% confidence interval for the difference in the overall percentage of AEs between Hospital A and Hospital B?
questionList.explanationText:
A confidence interval (CI) is constructed by taking a sample value (eg, difference in sample percentages) and adding and subtracting a margin of error.  Consequently, the interval always contains the sample value, and the sample value is typically at the center of the interval.  The CI of a given difference in percentages indicates, with a certain confidence level (eg, 95%), whether the difference in percentages is significantly different from the null value (ie, the null value for a difference = 0).  A CI that includes the null value is not statistically significant, and a CI that excludes the null value is statistically significant.

In this study, researchers randomly selected medical records of hospitalized patients from 2 university hospitals (Hospital A and Hospital B) to estimate and compare their percentage of adverse events (AEs), as well as the percentage of AEs due to negligence.  Results were as follows:

  • The percentage of overall AEs in Hospital A was 3.6% and in Hospital B was 5.1% for a difference of −1.5% that was statistically significant (p = 0.003).  The p-value corresponds to a test of a difference of percentages equal to 0, so a significant result means that the difference in the percentage of AEs between hospitals is significantly different from 0.

  • The percentage of AEs due to negligence in Hospital A was 27.7% and for Hospital B was 28.1% for a difference of −0.4% that was not statistically significant (p = 0.52).  Therefore, the difference in the percentage of AEs due to negligence between hospitals is not significantly different from 0.

Because the difference in the percentage of AEs between hospitals is significantly different from 0, a 95% CI for the same difference in percentages will exclude 0 (Choices D, E, and F).  The interval always contains the sample value (ie, difference in sample percentages), so −1.5% must be included in the interval (Choice C) and at its center (Choice A).  Therefore, the 95% CI for the difference in the percentage of AEs between Hospital A and Hospital B is most likely (−2.5% to −0.5%).

Educational objective:
A confidence interval (CI) always contains the sample value at the center of the interval.  A CI that excludes a null value (ie, difference in percentages = 0) is statistically significant.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: P-value and confidence interval

questionList.questionText: A clinical trial is designed to study the effectiveness of a new treatment to lower serum triglyceride levels in adults compared to the standard treatment.  The researcher determined that a total of 320 patients (160 in each treatment group) would be needed to have a power of 80% to detect a difference in mean serum triglycerides of 25 mg/dL between the groups at a 0.05 significance level.  At the end of the trial, the researcher reported a power of 92%.  Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questionList.explanationText:
Statistical power describes a study's ability to detect an effect (eg, difference between groups) when one truly exists.  It is the probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis (H0).

Power is influenced by 4 interrelated factors:

  • Sample size:  Larger sample sizes produce distributions that are tighter around the means than smaller sample sizes, so the difference between distributions (eg, groups) is easier to detect.  Therefore, with all other factors fixed, a larger sample size gives a study greater power.

  • Variability (eg, standard deviation) of study outcome:  Outcomes with smaller variability produce distributions that are tighter around their means than outcomes with greater variability, so the difference between distributions (eg, groups) is easier to detect.  Therefore, with all other factors fixed, outcomes with a smaller variability give a study greater power.

  • Effect size (eg, difference between treatment groups):  Larger effect sizes produce distributions that are very distant from each other compared to smaller effect sizes, so the difference between distributions (eg, groups) is easier to detect.  Therefore, with all other factors fixed, a larger effect size gives a study greater power.

  • Significance level (alpha, α):  The significance level is the threshold used to establish the statistical significance of study results.  The lower the significance level of a study, the more difficult it is to detect differences that might exist.  Therefore, with all other factors fixed, higher significance levels give a study greater power.

In this question, the power of the study increased from 80% (before the study started) to 92% (at the end of the study).  Such an increase in statistical power can occur only if the study recruited a larger sample than determined by the power calculation (Choice C), the outcome had a smaller variability than expected (Choice E), the difference between groups (ie, effect size) was greater than expected, or if the researcher used a higher significance level to establish statistical significance (Choice B).  Therefore, the most likely explanation for the power increase in this study is that the difference in mean serum triglycerides (ie, effect size) was greater than expected.

(Choice D)  The time it takes to complete a study has no bearing on the power of a study.

Educational objective:
Power describes a study's ability to detect an effect (eg, difference between groups) when one truly exists.  Power is influenced by 4 factors, as follows:

  • ↑ sample size ↑ power
  • ↓ outcome variability ↑ power
  • ↑ effect size ↑ power
  • ↑ significance level ↑ power
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Power and sample size

answerChoiceList.choice: The difference in mean serum triglycerides was greater than expected.
The researcher used a smaller significance level.
The sample size was reduced due to attrition.
The study was completed in a shorter amount time than expected.
The variability of serum triglycerides was greater than expected.

questionList.questionText:
A study was done to evaluate a new serologic screening test for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.  A total of 1000 people were randomly selected from the population, screened using the new test, and screened again using the gold standard (i.e., Western blot analysis) to determine true infection state.  The findings are as follows:

Test Results

True HIV Infection

No HIV Infection

Total

Positive

140

60

200

Negative

40

760

800

Total

180

820

1000

What is the sensitivity of this new serologic screening test?
questionList.explanationText:
Sensitivity and specificity are used to measure a test's validity.  Sensitivity is defined as the proportion of positive test results among the subjects with the disease.  Specificity is defined as the proportion of negative test results among the subjects without the disease.

Test Results

Disease Present

Disease Absent

Total

Positive

A
True positive (TP)

B
False positive (FP)

A + B

Negative

C
False negative (FN)

D
True negative (TN)

C + D

Total

A + C

B + D

A + B + C + D

Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) = A / (A + C)

Sensitivity determines how well the test identifies the people with the disease.  It is usually the first test used, similar to the use of a screening test when there is a public health threat.  The true-positive rate describes the sensitivity of the test.

Specificity = TN / (TN + FP) = D / (B + D)

Specificity determines how well the test identifies the people without the disease.  The true-negative rate describes the specificity of the test.

A perfectly valid diagnostic test should have sensitivity and specificity equal to 1, but this is seldom possible.  The more sensitive the test, the less specific it is (and vice versa).

In this example, the sensitivity is 140/180.

Educational objective:
Know how to calculate the sensitivity and specificity of a test.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity and specificity

questionList.questionText: A neurologist researching patients with stroke wants to study the association between cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) concentrations of T-tau as an explanatory variable and brain atrophy (measured quantitatively using 2 outcome variables: ventricular volume and total brain volume) 1 year poststroke.  A total of 210 patients with first-ever ischemic stroke or transitory ischemic attack without preexisting cognitive impairment are included in the study.  After 12 months, CSF biomarkers (including T-tau protein levels) are assessed.  In addition, subjects undergo MRI, and brain atrophy is estimated based on calculations of ventricular CSF volume and total brain volume normalized for subject head size.  Which of the following is the best statistical technique to describe the association between the explanatory and the outcome variables?
questionList.explanationText:
Dependent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Quantitative

Independent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Chi-square, logistic regression*

t test, ANOVA, linear regression

Quantitative

Logistic regression*

Correlation, linear regression

*Dependent variable must be dichotomous.

ANOVA =  analysis of variance.

Variables are broadly classified as qualitative (ie, categorical) or quantitative (eg, continuous) based on their scale of measurement.  Qualitative variables (eg, type of treatment, blood type) represent categories or groups whereas quantitative variables (eg, temperature, glucose level) represent numeric values.  The scale of measurement of the dependent (eg, outcome) and independent (eg, explanatory) variables in a study determines the correct statistical test.

Linear regression analysis is used to describe the association between:

  • 1 quantitative dependent (ie, outcome) variable.  In this study, brain atrophy (evaluated using 2 quantitative variables: ventricular volume and total brain volume) is the quantitative outcome variable.

  • ≥1 independent (ie, explanatory) variables, which may be quantitative or qualitative.  In this study, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) concentration of T-tau is a quantitative explanatory variable.

A regression analysis can determine whether CSF concentration of T-tau (explanatory variable) is significantly associated with brain atrophy (outcome variable).  However, given that the study measures brain atrophy through 2 different variables (ie, ventricular volume, total brain volume), 2 different regression models are required: one to evaluate the association between CSF concentrations of T-tau and ventricular volume and one to evaluate the association between CSF concentrations of T-tau and total brain volume.  Regression analyses may or may not adjust for other variables of interest.

(Choice A)  The analysis of variance (ANOVA) compares the mean of a quantitative dependent variable in several independent groups.  For example, ANOVA could be used to compare mean serum triglyceride level in patients with low, normal, or high serum uric acid levels (3 groups).

(Choice B)  The chi-square test evaluates the association between 2 categorical variables, as in a study evaluating the association between sex (male, female) and myocardial infarction (presence, absence).

(Choices D and E)  Odds ratio (OR) and relative risk (RR) measure the strength of the association between 2 categorical variables:  a categorical explanatory variable (eg, smoker, nonsmoker) and a categorical outcome or disease (eg, presence or absence of myocardial infarction).  The OR is used in case-control studies, and the RR is used in cohort studies.

Educational objective:
A regression analysis is a statistical technique used to describe the effect of ≥1 quantitative or qualitative independent (ie, explanatory) variables on 1 quantitative dependent (ie, outcome) variable.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Statistical tests

questionList.questionText: A new test is devised to detect HIV.  It has a sensitivity of 90% and specificity of 85% compared to the gold standard.  The test is used in 2 populations: a population in Africa with a 20% prevalence of HIV, and a population in Asia with a 1% prevalence of HIV.  Which of the following is the most accurate statement concerning the new test?
questionList.explanationText:
The positive predictive value (PPV) of a diagnostic test answers the following question: what is the probability that a patient has the disease given a positive test result?  PPV depends on disease prevalence in the population.  If disease prevalence is high (eg, 20% prevalence of HIV in the African population), an individual in that population will be more likely to have the disease.  Therefore, the probability that a patient from that population who tests positive actually has the disease is high (true positive result).  The greater the prevalence, the greater the PPV.  Conversely, if disease prevalence is low (eg, 1% prevalence of HIV in the Asian population), the probability that a patient who tests positive actually has the disease is low (false positive result).

The negative predictive value (NPV) of a diagnostic test answers the following question: what is the probability that a patient does not have the disease given a negative test result?  Like PPV, the NPV of a test depends on disease prevalence.  However, unlike PPV, NPV decreases as prevalence increases and increases as prevalence decreases.  If disease prevalence is low (eg, 1% prevalence of HIV in the Asian population), the probability that a patient who tests negative does not actually have the disease is high (true negative result) (Choice A).  If disease prevalence is high, the probability that a patient who tested negative does not actually have the disease is low (false negative result).

(Choices C and D)  The sensitivity and specificity of a test do not depend on disease prevalence.

(Choice E)  The validity of a test refers to its ability to identify diseased and non-diseased individuals.  The statement that the test is not valid in the African population is incorrect because the test has high sensitivity and specificity.

Educational objective:
Both the positive predictive value (PPV) and negative predictive value (NPV) of a test depend on the prevalence of the disease of interest in the population in which the test is applied.  PPV increases and NPV decreases with an increase in prevalence.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity, specificity, NPV, PPV

answerChoiceList.choice: The negative predictive value of the test is lower in the Asian population
The positive predictive value of the test is higher in the African population
The sensitivity of the test is higher in the African population
The specificity of the test is higher in the Asian population
The test is not valid in the African population

questionList.questionText: A group of investigators is planning a study to evaluate the relationship between serum fibrinogen levels and the incidence of acute coronary syndrome.  They assume that serum fibrinogen levels are normally distributed in the population of interest.  Which of the following statements is most consistent with this assumption?
questionList.explanationText:
The normal distribution is one of the most commonly occurring statistical distributions.  Many variables in real life (eg, laboratory values) are normally distributed or close to normal.  The normal distribution is bell-shaped and symmetric.  Consequently, all its measures of central tendency are equal: mean = median = mode.  (In real life, the values are not exactly equal due to small variations, but they lie very close to each other.)  Skewed distributions do not have this property.

(Choices B and C)  In a positively skewed distribution (tail on the right), the mean is greater than the median and greater than the mode.

(Choices D and E)  In a negatively skewed distribution (tail on the left), the mean is less than the median and less than the mode.

Educational objective:
A normal distribution is symmetric and bell-shaped.  All its measures of central tendency are equal: mean = median = mode.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Normal distribution

questionList.questionText: In a multicenter, double-blind, randomized placebo-controlled trial, 400 adult patients with difficult-to-treat papulopustular rosacea are randomly assigned to oral isotretinoin or placebo (1:1 ratio).  The primary endpoint after the 4-month treatment period is at least 90% reduction of the number of papules/pustules compared with baseline.  Analysis shows that 128 patients treated with isotretinoin and 60 patients receiving placebo reached the primary endpoint at the end of treatment.  Results also show that 138 patients treated with isotretinoin and 88 patients receiving placebo had at least 1 treatment-related adverse event (AE).  The differences in rates of response and AE are statistically significant.  Which of the following is the approximate number of patients who must be exposed to isotretinoin to cause harm to 1 person who otherwise would not have been harmed?
questionList.explanationText:
The number of people who must be exposed to a treatment to cause harm to 1 person who otherwise would not have been harmed is known as the number needed to harm (NNH).  It is calculated in a manner similar to the number needed to treat (NNT) but using the absolute risk increase (ARI) instead of the absolute risk reduction (ARR):

NNH = (1 / ARI)

ARI is the difference in the rate (risk) of the adverse event (AE) between the treatment group (eg, isotretinoin) and the control group (eg, placebo):

ARI = (RateAE,isotretinoin − RateAE,placebo)

In this study, the rate of treatment-related AEs in the treatment group (ie, isotretinoin) is 138/200 = 0.69 (or 69%) and in the control group (ie, placebo) is 88/200 = 0.44 (or 44%).  Therefore, the ARI in adverse events of isotretinoin versus placebo is:

ARI = (RateAE,isotretinoin − RateAE,placebo) = 0.69 − 0.44 = 0.25 (or 25%) (Choice C)

Consequently, the NNH is:

NNH = (1 / ARI) = 1 / 0.25 = 4

Therefore, approximately 4 patients would need to be treated with isotretinoin to cause harm to 1 person who otherwise would not have been harmed.  The lower the NNH, the more risk of harm; an NNH of 1 means that every patient treated is harmed.

(Choices A, D, and E)  The absolute risk reduction (ARR) is the difference in risk of an unfavorable event (eg, treatment nonresponse) between the isotretinoin and placebo groups: ARR = (Rateplacebo − Rateisotretinoin).  In this case, the rate of response to treatment (ie, reaching the primary endpoint) in the isotretinoin group is 128/200 = 0.64 and in the placebo group is 60/200 = 0.30, so their rate of nonresponse is 1 − 0.64 = 0.36 and 1 − 0.30 = 0.70, respectively.  Therefore, ARR = 0.70 − 0.36 = 0.34 (or 34%).  The relative risk reduction (RRR) is (Rateplacebo − Rateisotretinoin) / Rateplacebo, so RRR = (0.70 − 0.36) / 0.70 ≈ 0.49 (or 49%).  The NNT to avoid 1 additional negative event (ie, no treatment response) compared to placebo is the inverse of the ARR: NNT = 1 / ARR = 1 / 0.34 ≈ 3.

Educational objective:
The number needed to harm (NNH) is the number of people who must be exposed to a treatment to cause harm to 1 person who otherwise would not have been harmed.  To calculate the NNH, the absolute risk increase (ARI) between the treatment and control groups must be known: NNH = 1 / ARI.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Number needed to harm

questionList.questionText: A study of serum cholesterol levels in patients with diabetes mellitus reveals that the parameter is normally distributed with a mean of 230 mg/dL and standard deviation of 10 mg/dL.  Within the study population, 95% of serum cholesterol observations will lie between which of the following limits?
questionList.explanationText:
A normal distribution refers to a symmetrical, bell-shaped distribution pattern with a fixed proportion of observations that lie within a certain distance from the mean.  This distance is called the standard deviation (SD) and is a measure of the degree of dispersion from the mean.  For a normal distribution, approximately 95% of all values are within 2 SDs from the mean.  In this case, the standard deviation is 10 mg/dL and the mean is 230 mg/dL.  Therefore, 95% of all observations will be between 210 mg/dL and 250 mg/dL.

(Choice A)  99.7% of all observations lie within 3 SDs from the mean.

(Choice C)  68% of all observations lie within 1 SD from the mean.

(Choice D)  For normal distributions, SDs are symmetric around the mean.

(Choice E)  This interval describes values that lie within 0.5 SD of the mean.

Educational objective:
In a normal (bell-shaped) distribution:
68% of all values are within 1 standard deviation from the mean
95% of all values are within 2 standard deviations from the mean
99.7% of all values are within 3 standard deviations from the mean
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Standard deviation

questionList.questionText: A randomized, double-blind trial is conducted that evaluated the effect of benazepril plus amlodipine (intervention) compared to benazepril plus hydrochlorothiazide (control) for hypertension in high-risk patients.  A total of 11,203 patients with hypertension who were at high risk for cardiovascular events were randomly assigned to receive treatment with either benazepril plus amlodipine (n = 5,544) or benazepril plus hydrochlorothiazide (n = 5,659).  The primary end point was the composite of death from cardiovascular causes, nonfatal myocardial infarction, nonfatal stroke, hospitalization for angina, resuscitation after sudden cardiac arrest, and coronary revascularization.  There were 552 primary-outcome events in the benazepril-amlodipine group and 679 in the benazepril-hydrochlorothiazide group.  Difference between groups was statistically significant (p < 0.001).  Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of these results?
questionList.explanationText:
Common measures of therapeutic efficacy

Term

Definition

Calculation

Absolute risk reduction (ARR)

Percentage indicating the actual difference in event rate between control & treatment groups

ARR = control rate – treatment rate

Relative risk reduction (RRR)

Percentage indicating relative reduction in the treatment event rate compared to the control group

RRR = ARR / control rate

Relative risk (RR)

Ratio of the probability of an event occurring in the treatment group compared to the control group

RR = treatment rate / control rate

Number needed to treat (NNT)

Number of individuals who need to be treated to prevent a negative outcome in 1 patient

NNT = 1 / ARR

Relative risk reduction (RRR) describes the difference in risk (or rate) of an unfavorable outcome (eg, composite of death from cardiovascular causes, nonfatal myocardial infarction, nonfatal stroke) between a treatment group (eg, benazepril-amlodipine treatment) and a control group (eg, benazepril-hydrochlorothiazide treatment) relative to the control group (ie, proportion of decreased risk due to treatment compared to the control group).  RRR is calculated as follows:

RRR = (Riskcontrol − Risktreatment) / Riskcontrol

In this question, Riskcontrol and Risktreatment must be calculated first based on the information given:

  • The number of primary-outcome events in the benazepril-hydrochlorothiazide (control) group is 679, and the total number of patients assigned to this treatment is 5,659:

Riskcontrol = 679 / 5,659 ≈ 0.12

  • The number of primary-outcome events in the benazepril-amlodipine (treatment) group is 552, and the total number of patients assigned to this treatment is 5,544:

Risktreatment = 552 / 5,544 ≈ 0.10

Therefore, RRR for primary-outcome events in the benazepril-amlodipine (treatment) group is calculated as:

RRR = (0.12 − 0.10) / 0.12 ≈ 0.17

Alternatively, RRR may be calculated using relative risk (RR):

RRR = 1 − RR

For this question, RR is the ratio of the risk of primary-outcome events in the benazepril-amlodipine (treatment) group to the risk of primary-outcome events in the benazepril-hydrochlorothiazide (control) group.  It is calculated as:

RR = (Risktreatment / Riskcontrol) = (0.10 / 0.12) ≈ 0.83 (Choices C and D)

Therefore:

RRR = 1 − 0.83 = 0.17

Note that the formula for RRR based on RR can be derived from the formula for RRR based on the difference in rates:

RRR = (Riskcontrol − Risktreatment) / Riskcontrol = 1 − (Risktreatment / Riskcontrol) = 1 − RR

(Choices A, B, and E)  Absolute risk reduction (ARR) describes the absolute difference in risk of an unfavorable outcome (eg, primary-outcome events) between a treatment group (eg, benazepril-amlodipine) and a control group (eg, benazepril-hydrochlorothiazide).  It is calculated as: ARR = (Riskcontrol − Risktreatment) = 0.12 − 0.10 = 0.02.

Educational objective:
Relative risk reduction (RRR) measures how much a treatment reduces the risk (ie, rate) of an unfavorable outcome.  RRR may be calculated using absolute risk reduction (ARR) or relative risk (RR) as follows:

RRR = ARR / Riskcontrol = (Riskcontrol − Risktreatment) / Riskcontrol

RRR = 1 − RR = 1 − (Risktreatment / Riskcontrol)
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Risk

questionList.questionText: A case-control study evaluated the association between chronic cerebrospinal venous insufficiency (CCSVI) and multiple sclerosis (MS).  The study enrolled 150 patients with newly diagnosed MS and 210 healthy individuals (controls) matched by age and sex.  Transcranial and echo color Doppler ultrasound examinations were performed on all 360 subjects.  CCSVI was present in 25 (~16.67%) patients with MS and in 10 (~4.76%) healthy individuals.  Based on these results, which of the following is closest to the odds ratio of CCSVI in patients with MS relative to controls?
questionList.explanationText:
The odds of an event are related to the probability (P) of that event, with odds equal to P / (1 − P).  For example, the probability of rolling a die and getting a 1 is 1/6, but the odds of rolling a 1 are 1/5.  The odds ratio (OR) is a measure of association used in case-control studies to compare the odds of exposure in cases (ie, individuals with disease) relative to controls (ie, individuals without disease):

OR = (odds of exposure in cases) / (odds of exposure in controls)

A shortcut to calculate the OR when a contingency table has a standard format (ie, exposure of interest in the first row of exposure status and cases in the first column of disease status) is the following:

OR = (a/c) / (b/d)

In this study, the disease of interest is multiple sclerosis (MS), so cases are patients with MS and controls are persons without MS (ie, healthy individuals).  The exposure of interest is evidence of chronic cerebrospinal venous insufficiency (CCSVI), so the reference category of exposure is no evidence of CCSVI.  Given that 25 of 150 patients with MS had evidence of CCSVI, 150 − 25 = 125 patients with MS had no evidence of CCSVI.  Given that 10 of 210 healthy individuals had evidence of CCSVI, 210 − 10 = 200 healthy controls had no evidence of CCSVI.  Based on these data, the standard contingency table is as follows:

MS +

MS −

CCSVI +

25

(a)

10

(b)

CCSVI −

125

(c)

200

(d)

Total

150

210

The odds of CCSVI in patients with MS and healthy individuals (controls) are calculated as follows:

  • Odds of CCSVI in cases: a/c = 25/125 = 0.2
  • Odds of CCSVI in controls: b/d = 10/200 = 0.05

Therefore, the OR of CCSVI in patients with MS relative to healthy controls is:

OR = (odds of CCSVI in cases) / (odds of CCSVI in controls) = (a/c) / (b/d) = 0.2/0.05 = 4.0

The estimated OR = 4.0 is >1 (ie, null value for the OR); this indicates that CCSVI acts as a risk factor for MS.

This example calculates the OR of exposure (ie, odds of exposure among cases relative to controls).  The OR is sometimes described as the odds of disease among exposed individuals relative to nonexposed individuals, given by (a/b) / (c/d).  These two OR definitions are mathematically equivalent and reduce to OR = ad / bc.

Educational objective:
The odds ratio (OR) is a measure of association calculated as follows:

OR = (odds of exposure in cases) / (odds of exposure in controls)

For a contingency table in the standard format:

OR = ad / bc
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Measures of association

questionList.questionText: A physician working in a group practice that offers services at 2 locations (Location 1 and Location 2) conducted a study to estimate the crude cause-specific mortality rate for heart disease at both service locations.  The physician determined that the estimated crude mortality rate for heart disease at Location 1 is half the estimated crude mortality rate for Location 2.  Additional analyses based on national data revealed no difference in the age-standardized mortality rates for heart disease between service locations.  Which of the following statements is consistent with the results of the study?
questionList.explanationText:
The cause-specific crude mortality rate (CMR) is the mortality rate from a specific cause (eg, heart disease) for a population.  It is obtained by dividing the number of deaths attributed to a specific cause by the population size (at the midpoint of a period of interest).  The fraction is usually expressed per 100,000 population.  A disadvantage of using crude rates to compare mortality between populations is that crude rates are influenced by the underlying age distributions of the populations.  Because mortality increases with age (eg, for heart disease), CMRs may provide misleading information when comparing populations that have different underlying age distributions (eg, an older population will likely have a higher CMR for heart disease than a young population).

One way to increase the comparability of mortality rates from different populations is to correct for any difference in underlying age distributions.  The cause-specific age-standardized mortality rate (ASMR) eliminates the effect of the difference in the underlying age distributions of the populations being compared.  It does so by using weighted averages of the age-specific death rates of a given population; the weights correspond to the underlying age distribution of that population.

In this case, the effect of correcting for age distribution differences is as follows:

  • The estimated CMRs indicated a marked difference in mortality from heart disease between Locations 1 and 2 (ie, CMR at Location 1 was half that of Location 2).

  • However, ASMRs indicated no difference in mortality from heart disease between Locations 1 and 2.

This discrepancy indicates that the greater mortality suggested by the CMR estimates arose from a difference in the underlying distributions of age of patients seeking services at Locations 1 and 2 (Choice C) and not from a real difference in mortality due to heart disease (Choices A and B).

The CMR at Location 1 was half that of Location 2, which suggests that patients seeking services at Location 2 are older compared to those seeking services at Location 1 (Choice D).  Therefore, although there is no real difference in mortality due to heart disease between the 2 locations, patients seeking services at Location 1 are younger than patients seeking services at Location 2.

Educational objective:
The age-standardized mortality rate is a measure of mortality that eliminates the effect of the difference in the underlying age distributions of the populations being compared.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Morbidity and mortality rates

answerChoiceList.choice: Mortality from heart disease in elderly persons is lower at Location 1 compared to Location 2
Mortality from heart disease in young adults is lower at Location 1 compared to Location 2
Patients seeking services at Location 1 and Location 2 have similar age distributions
Patients seeking services at Location 1 are older than patients seeking services at Location 2
Patients seeking services at Location 1 are younger than patients seeking services at Location 2

questionList.questionText: In a selected study of bronchogenic cancer, it was found that in people smoking 1 pack per day (PPD) of cigarettes, the relative risk (RR) was 2.4.  For those smoking 2 PPD, the RR was 3.0.  For those smoking 3 PPD, the RR was 4.1.  The corresponding p-values for these RRs were all <0.05 with no overlap in the corresponding confidence intervals.  Which of the following statements is true regarding these findings?
questionList.explanationText:
Relative risk (RR) is used as a measure of association in cohort studies.  It is the ratio of the risk in the exposed group to that in the unexposed group.  A RR >1 means that there is a positive association between the risk factor and the outcome.  A RR <1 means that there is a negative association between the risk factor and the outcome.  The farther the value of RR from 1, the stronger the association.  In the example, the RR for bronchogenic cancer in smokers is >2, thereby indicating a strong association between smoking (risk factor/exposure) and bronchogenic cancer (outcome).

When exposure is measured on a continuous scale (eg, number of packs per day [PPD]), the classification in 2 or more ordinal categories enables the risk to be assessed as a function of exposure, and the dose-response effect can be calculated for the exposure and outcome.  This example illustrates a dose-response relationship between smoking and bronchogenic cancer (ie, the RR for bronchogenic cancer increases as the number of smoked PPD increases).

(Choices A, B, C, and E)  In the study, there was a strong association between cigarette smoking and bronchogenic cancer.  There was also a clear dose-response relationship between smoked PPD and bronchogenic cancer.

Educational objective:
Know how to interpret the strength of association and dose-response relationship from a study.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Risk

answerChoiceList.choice: Cigarette smoking and bronchogenic cancer had a strength of association, but the dose-response relationship was not clear
Smoking and bronchogenic cancer did not have strength of association, but had a dose-response relationship
Smoking and bronchogenic cancer were weakly associated and did not show a clear dose-response relationship
Smoking and bronchogenic cancer had a strong association and a dose-response relationship
Smoking and bronchogenic cancer had strength of association but no dose-response relationship

questionList.questionText: A university hospital conducted a study to determine the effect of type of attending physician supervision of inpatient residents on patient safety and educational outcomes.  Fifty attending physicians provided either (1) increased direct supervision in which attending physicians joined rounds on previously admitted patients or (2) standard supervision in which attending physicians were available but did not join patient rounds.  Residents then were randomly assigned to either type of attending physician supervision.  One of the outcomes studied was total duration of patient rounds measured in minutes.  Which of the following statistical tests is adequate to determine whether type of attending physician supervision has an effect on the average duration of work rounds of residents?
questionList.explanationText:
Dependent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Quantitative

Independent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Chi-square, logistic regression*

t test, ANOVA, linear regression

Quantitative

Logistic regression*

Correlation, linear regression

*Dependent variable must be dichotomous.

ANOVA =  analysis of variance.

Variables are broadly classified as qualitative (ie, categorical) or quantitative (ie, continuous) based on the scale of measurement.  Qualitative variables (eg, type of treatment, blood type) represent categories or groups, whereas quantitative variables (eg, temperature, glucose level) represent numerical values.  The scale of measurement of the dependent (eg, outcome) and independent (eg, exposure, risk factor) variables in a study determines the correct statistical test for any given situation.

A t-test compares the mean of 2 groups.  It requires: a categorical independent variable (eg, exposure) that is used to divide study participants into 2 groups; and a quantitative dependent variable (eg, outcome) for which an average (ie, mean) is calculated.  An independent samples t-test is used when 2 groups are independent (ie, when observations in a sample are unrelated to observations in another sample), and a paired t-test is used when 2 groups are dependent (ie, each observation in a sample is paired [matched] with an observation from another sample).  In this study:

  • The quantitative dependent variable is duration of patient rounds (for which an average is calculated, in minutes).

  • The categorical independent variable is type of attending physician supervision (with categories "increased direct supervision" and "standard supervision").

The residents in one supervision group were not matched to residents in the other supervision group; therefore, the groups are independent.  An independent samples t-test will determine whether there is a statistically significant difference in mean duration of patient rounds between groups.  A large, statistically significant difference in means indicates that type of attending physician supervision affects the duration of patient rounds of residents.

(Choice A)  The chi-square test evaluates the association between 2 categorical variables, as in a study evaluating the association between sex (male, female) and myocardial infarction (presence of myocardial infarction, absence of myocardial infarction).  In this example, the dependent variable (work rounds) is quantitative.

(Choice B)  A correlation analysis uses the correlation coefficient to describe the linear relationship between 2 quantitative variables, as in a study evaluating the linear relationship between stress level and irritability score.  In this case, the independent variable (ie, type of supervision) is categorical and the dependent variable (ie, minutes) is quantitative.

(Choice D)  Meta-analysis is a quantitative statistical technique used to combine and analyze data from several studies to conduct an analysis with a greater statistical power than that of the individual studies.

Educational objective:
The independent samples t-test compares the mean of 2 independent groups.  The test requires that a quantitative dependent variable (eg, outcome) be evaluated in 2 independent groups.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Statistical tests

questionList.questionText:
A group of endocrinologists conducted a randomized controlled trial to compare the efficacy of capsaicin versus turpentine oil for topical treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy.  Patients were randomly assigned to topical application of either capsaicin (Group A) or commercially available turpentine oil (Group B) over a painful site on their feet.  The primary outcome was significant reduction in pain on visual analogue scale (VAS), and treatment efficacy defined as ≥3-point reduction on VAS.  An excerpt of the study results is shown below.

Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to determine whether there is a statistically significant difference in treatment efficacy between the 2 groups?
questionList.explanationText:
Dependent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Quantitative

Independent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Chi-square, logistic regression*

t test, ANOVA, linear regression

Quantitative

Logistic regression*

Correlation, linear regression

*Dependent variable must be dichotomous.

ANOVA =  analysis of variance.

Variables are broadly classified as qualitative (ie, categorical) or quantitative (ie, continuous) based on the scale of measurement.  Qualitative variables (eg, type of treatment, blood type) represent categories or groups whereas quantitative variables (eg, temperature, glucose level) represent numerical values.  The scale of measurement of the dependent (eg, outcome) and independent (eg, exposure, risk factor) variables in a study determines the correct statistical test for any given situation.

A chi-square test determines whether the distribution of a categorical outcome (ie, categorical/qualitative dependent variable) is different across ≥2 independent groups (ie, categorical/qualitative independent variable).  In this study:

  • The categorical dependent variable is treatment efficacy, with 2 categories: "efficacious" (defined as a ≥3-point reduction on the visual analogue scale [VAS] for pain) and "not efficacious."
  • The independent groups are Group A (ie, capsaicin) and Group B (ie, turpentine oil).

A chi-square test will determine whether a statistically significant difference in efficacy exists between the 2 groups.  The test only applies if the groups are independent, where observations in one sample (Group A) are unrelated to observations in another sample (Group B).

(Choice B)  A correlation analysis uses the correlation coefficient to describe the linear relationship between 2 quantitative variables, as in a study evaluating the linear relationship between hours of sleep and irritability score.

(Choice C)  Meta-analysis is a quantitative statistical technique used to combine and analyze data from several studies to conduct an analysis with a greater statistical power than that of the individual studies.

(Choice D)  Two-sample t-test for means compares the mean of a quantitative variable of 2 independent groups, as in a study comparing serum ferritin concentrations (ie, quantitative variable) in male and female patients.  Although VAS is a quantitative tool, efficacy in this study is used as a qualitative variable, with "efficacious" defined as a ≥3-point reduction on VAS.

(Choice E)  Survival (also known as "time to event") analysis estimates the time for ≥1 experimental groups to experience an event of interest.  Although it considers the number of events in each experimental group, the analysis focuses on the timing of the events in each experimental group throughout the follow-up period.

Educational objective:
A chi-square test determines whether the distribution of a categorical outcome (ie, dependent variable) is different across ≥2 independent groups (ie, independent variable).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Statistical tests

questionList.questionText:
A new test has been devised to detect lung carcinoma.  The levels of the enzyme corresponding to diseased states are being determined.  A random number of smokers are sorted (ie, with and without lung carcinoma) and the corresponding enzyme levels are determined.

At what cut-off value (ie, enzyme level) will the number of false negatives be the highest?
questionList.explanationText:
False negatives (FN) pertain to the patients who have a negative test result despite actually having the disease (ie, those who are incorrectly labelled as healthy or without disease).  When the cut-off level of a diagnostic test is raised (eg, from point A up to point B; or from any of the points listed up to point E), the FN will also consequently increase.

(Choices A, B, C and D)  Cut-off points A, B, C, D will result in lower false negative values.

Educational objective:

False negatives will increase when the cut-off level of a diagnostic test is raised.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity and specificity

questionList.questionText: A group of investigators conducted a randomized placebo-controlled clinical trial to assess the effect of a new aldosterone receptor antagonist on the progression of chronic heart failure.  The primary outcome was all-cause mortality.  A decrease in all-cause mortality in the treatment group was reported, with a relative risk of 0.71 (p = 0.001).  Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the reported association?
questionList.explanationText:
Relative risk (RR) is a point estimate of association, but it does not account for random error.  It is always possible that the calculated RR occurred by chance.  The p-value is used to strengthen the results of the study and represents the probability of observing a given (or more extreme) result by chance alone, assuming the null hypothesis is true.  In this scenario, assuming there were no difference in all-cause mortality between the treatment and placebo groups (null hypothesis), the probability of obtaining a RR of 0.71 or a more extreme value due to chance alone is 0.1% (ie, p = 0.001 because 0.1/100 = 0.001).  The commonly accepted upper limit (cut-off point) of the p-value for a result to be considered statistically significant is 0.05 (ie, p <5% is statistically significant).

(Choices A and E)  Both the p-value and the confidence interval are measures of statistical significance.  A 95% confidence interval that contains 1.0 (null value for RR) would mean that the results are not statistically significant.  This is not consistent with the obtained p-value of 0.001, which is statistically significant.

(Choice C)  A RR = 0.71 shows that the drug decreased the risk of mortality by 29% (as 1.0 - 0.71 = 0.29 or 29%).

(Choice D)  The p-value reflects random variability, not bias (which is systematic error).

Educational objective:
The p-value is the probability of observing a given (or more extreme) result due to chance alone, assuming the null hypothesis is true.  A result is generally considered statistically significant when p <0.05.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: P-value and confidence interval

answerChoiceList.choice: The 95% confidence interval for the relative risk of all-cause mortality includes 1.0
There is a 0.1% probability of observing the given relative risk (or more extreme) by chance alone assuming no differences in mortality
There is a 71% decrease in all-cause mortality in the new aldosterone receptor antagonist compared to the placebo group
There is only a 0.1% chance that the relative risk calculated is biased in favor of the aldosterone receptor antagonist group
The results obtained are not statistically significant

questionList.questionText:
A group of researchers conducted a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to study the effectiveness of mercaptopurine and Lactobacillus to prevent recurrence of Crohn disease after surgical resection.  Six-hundred patients were randomly assigned to daily mercaptopurine, Lactobacillus, or placebo (ratio: 1:1:1) and followed up for 3 years.  Clinical recurrence of Crohn disease was determined based on the Crohn Disease Activity Index (CDAI), with a score >150 indicating recurrence.  The primary endpoint was a significant increase in the CDAI (defined as a 100-point increase in score, with CDAI >150) and the need for anti-inflammatory rescue treatment or primary surgical intervention.  An excerpt of the study results is shown below.

Treatment

3-year clinical* recurrence rate

p-value†

Mercaptopurine

13%

0.009

Lactobacillus

16%

0.077

Placebo

23%

-

*Crohn Disease Activity Index (CDAI) >150 plus 100-point increase in score and the need for anti-inflammatory rescue treatment or primary surgical intervention.

†Compared to placebo.

The researchers decide to focus their attention on the effectiveness of mercaptopurine in preventing clinical recurrence events after surgical resection within 3 years compared with placebo.  They estimate the number needed to treat to be 10.  Which of the following is the correct interpretation of this value?
questionList.explanationText:
The number needed to treat (NNT) represents the number of patients who need to be exposed to a treatment (eg, mercaptopurine) to prevent 1 additional adverse outcome (eg, clinical recurrence) in a particular time period (eg, 3 years) compared with a different treatment or control (eg, placebo), assuming the treatment is beneficial.  In other words, the NNT compares the effects of 2 interventions in a specific group of people, on a specific outcome, during a predetermined time.  Therefore, the NNT will vary depending on the population under consideration, the treatments being compared, the outcomes of interest, and for how long the outcomes were observed.

In this case, researchers were interested in the effectiveness of mercaptopurine in preventing clinical recurrence of Crohn disease after surgical resection within 3 years compared with placebo.  They estimated the NNT at 10, based on an absolute risk reduction (ARR) between mercaptopurine and placebo as follows:

ARR = 23% − 13% = 10% = 0.1

NNT = 1 / ARR = 1 / 0.1 = 10

The correct interpretation for their findings would be that compared with placebo, 10 patients need to be treated with mercaptopurine after surgical resection to prevent 1 additional clinical recurrence within 3 years of treatment.

When interpreting the NNT, consider the following questions:

  • What is the baseline risk of patients in the study?
  • What is the comparison group?  (Choices B, C, and D)
  • What is the outcome?
  • How long does the study last?  (Choice A)

Educational objective:
The interpretation of the number needed to treat (NNT) should always include information about the comparison group, the specific outcome, and the period of observation for the outcome.  NNT values for the same intervention or treatment will vary depending on the outcome, the period of observation, and the comparison group used.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Number Needed To Treat

answerChoiceList.choice: 10 patients need to be treated with mercaptopurine after surgical resection to prevent 1 additional clinical recurrence
10 patients need to be treated with mercaptopurine after surgical resection to prevent 1 additional clinical recurrence within 3 years of treatment
Compared with Lactobacillus or placebo, 10 patients need to be treated with mercaptopurine after surgical resection to prevent 1 additional clinical recurrence within 3 years of treatment
Compared with Lactobacillus, 10 patients need to be treated with mercaptopurine after surgical resection to prevent 1 additional clinical recurrence within 3 years of treatment
Compared with placebo, 10 patients need to be treated with mercaptopurine after surgical resection to prevent 1 additional clinical recurrence within 3 years of treatment

questionList.questionText:
An oncologic research institute isolates an antigen associated with colon cancer.  A study is conducted to evaluate serum levels of the potential tumor marker in patients with suspected colon cancer who are undergoing colonoscopy at a regional gastroenterology clinic.  The following curves are generated using the results of the study.

Researchers decide to use the tumor antigen to develop an adjunct test for colon cancer in high-risk patients.  Assuming disease prevalence in the study group is similar to that in the target population, moving the cutoff point from B to A will change the positive predictive value in which of the following ways?
questionList.explanationText:
True positive (TP) - A patient with the disease who tests positive
False positive (FP) - A patient without the disease who tests positive
True negative (TN) - A patient without the disease who tests negative
False negative (FN) - A patient with the disease who tests negative

Positive predictive value (PPV) is one of several parameters used to assess the accuracy and utility of a diagnostic test.  PPV is the number of patients correctly testing positive divided by the total number of patients testing positive (TP / [TP + FP]).  Higher PPV means that a positive test result is more likely to be true.  PPV is related to both sensitivity and specificity, but it also depends on disease prevalence as it is calculated using both diseased patients (TPs) and healthy patients (FPs).

In this example, disease prevalence is approximately 50%, as the graph shows that the diseased and healthy groups contain an equal number of patients.  Moving the cutoff point from B to A will cause more patients with the disease to test positive (more TPs) and at the same time cause more patients without the disease to test positive (more FPs).  In this case, the increase in TPs happens to be the same as the increase in FPs (given the symmetry of lines A and B).  As a result, PPV decreases because PPV = (TP / [TP + FP]).  The exhibit demonstrates this calculation and illustrates how moving the cutoff point in a sample population of 200 subjects increases the number of TPs from 80 to 90, increases the number of FPs from 10 to 20, and decreases PPV from 0.89 to 0.82.

Educational objective:
Unlike sensitivity and specificity, positive and negative predictive values depend on the prevalence of disease in the population being tested.  A change in a test cutoff point that causes an increase in the number of false positives and true positives will decrease positive predictive value.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity, specificity, NPV, PPV

questionList.questionText:
The mean and standard deviation (SD) of height in adult men and women in the United States are shown below.

Height (inches)

Mean

SD

Men

70

3

Women

64.5

2.5

Assuming that the heights of men and women are approximately normally distributed, which of the following approximates the percentile of heights for an adult woman who is 69.5 inches tall?
questionList.explanationText:
A normal distribution is a symmetrical, bell-shaped distribution with a fixed percentage of observations lying within a certain distance of the mean.  This distance is called the standard deviation (SD) and represents the degree of dispersion of the data from the mean.

The 68-95-99.7 rule for a normal distribution states that 68% of all observations lie within 1 SD of the mean, 95% of all observations lie within 2 SDs of the mean, and 99.7% of all observations lie within 3 SDs of the mean.  A percentile is the value in a normal distribution that has a specific percentage of observations below it (ie, area under the curve to the left of the specific value).  It is possible to use the 68-95-99.7 rule to identify the percentiles that correspond to values that are 1, 2, or 3 SDs from the mean.

The heights of adult women in the United States are approximately normally distributed with a mean of 64.5 inches and a SD of 2.5 inches.  Based on the 68-95-99.7 rule:

  • 68% of heights of adult women lie within 1 SD: 64.5 ± 2.5 = 62-67
  • 95% of heights of adult women lie within 2 SDs: 64.5 ± 2(2.5) = 59.5-69.5
  • 99.7% of heights of adult women lie within 3 SDs: 64.5 ± 3(2.5) = 57-72

The height of an adult woman who is 69.5 inches tall is exactly 2 SDs above the mean height.  This means that 2.5% of heights must lie above 69.5 inches and 100% − 2.5% = 97.5% must lie below 69.5 inches (Choice A).  Therefore, an adult woman who is 69.5 inches tall is at the 97.5 percentile of the distribution.

(Choice B)  In a normal distribution, the 50th percentile approximates the mean of the distribution.  In this case, the mean height of adult women is 64.5 inches, so a height of 69.5 inches is at a higher percentile.

(Choices C and E)  68.0 and 99.7 represent the percentage of heights that are within 1 SD and 3 SDs from the mean, respectively.

Educational objective:
A percentile is the value in a normal distribution that has a specified percentage of observations below it (ie, area under the curve to the left of the specific value).  It is possible to use the 68-95-99.7 rule to identify the percentiles that correspond to values that are 1, 2, or 3 standard deviations from the mean.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Normal distribution

questionList.questionText:
A group of researchers investigated the potential of the pleiotropic growth factor midkine as a marker of thyroid cancer.  A total of 500 patients with thyroid cancer and 800 patients with no history of thyroid cancer were included in the study, and their serum midkine levels were measured.  The data analysis included a stratified analysis based on midkine levels.  An excerpt of the results is shown below.

Serum midkine levels
(in pg/mL)

Number of patients with
thyroid cancer

Number of patients with
no thyroid cancer

0-250.4

31

406

250.5-320.4

94

274

≥320.5

375

120

The researchers want to report the positive likelihood ratio associated with a serum midkine level ≥320.5 pg/mL.  Which of the following is closest to the value the researchers should report?
questionList.explanationText:
Common performance measures for diagnostic tests

Parameter

Definition

Calculation

Sensitivity

The probability of an individual testing positive given the presence of disease

Sensitivity = true positives / (true positives + false negatives)

Specificity

The probability of an individual testing negative given the absence of disease

Specificity = true negatives / (true negatives + false positives)

Positive predictive value (PPV)

The probability that an individual who tests positive actually has the disease

PPV = true positives / (true positives + false positives)

Negative predictive value (NPV)

The probability that an individual who tests negative actually does not have the disease

NPV = true negatives / (true negatives + false negatives)

Positive likelihood ratio (LR+)

The probability of an individual with the disease testing positive divided by the probability of an individual without the disease testing positive

LR+ = sensitivity / (1 − specificity)

Negative likelihood ratio (LR−)

The probability of an individual with the disease testing negative divided by the probability of an individual without the disease testing negative

LR− = (1 − sensitivity) / specificity

The likelihood ratio (LR) is the probability of finding an event (eg, positive or negative result on a diagnostic test) in patients with the disease divided by the probability of the same finding in patients without the disease.  LRs are useful for determining how a positive or negative diagnostic test result affects a patient's likelihood of having the disease.  LRs may be positive (LR+) or negative (LR−) and are calculated as follows:

LR+ = (probability of diseased patient testing positive) / (probability of nondiseased patient testing positive)

LR− = (probability of diseased patient testing negative) / (probability of nondiseased patient testing negative)

There are also formulae for LR based on sensitivity and specificity.

In this case, the researchers evaluated the diagnostic performance of the pleiotropic growth factor midkine as a marker of thyroid cancer.  The study included 500 patients with thyroid cancer and 800 without thyroid cancer.  The researchers want to report the LR+ associated with a serum midkine level ≥320.5 pg/mL.  Results are as follows:

  • In patients with thyroid cancer, 375 of 500 patients had a serum midkine level ≥320.5 pg/mL.  Therefore, the probability of a patient with thyroid cancer testing positive based on that cutoff is 375 / 500 = 0.75 or 75%.  This also means that the sensitivity (probability of testing positive given presence of disease) of the midkine test at that cutoff is 0.75 or 75%.

  • In patients without thyroid cancer, 120 of 800 patients had a serum midkine level ≥320.5 pg/mL.  Therefore, the probability of a patient without thyroid cancer testing positive based on that cutoff is 120 / 800 = 0.15 or 15% (Choice C).  This also means that the specificity (probability of testing negative given absence of disease) of the midkine test at that cutoff is (1 − 0.15) = 0.85 or 85%; this value can also be obtained by considering that 680 (= 800 − 120) of the 800 patients without thyroid cancer tested negative based on the cutoff (ie, 680/800 = 0.85 or 85%). (Choice D).

Based on these calculations, the researchers should report that the LR+ is 0.75 / 0.15 = 5.

Alternatively, the LR+ for that cutoff can be calculated using sensitivity and specificity as follows:

LR+ = sensitivity / (1 − specificity) = 0.75 / (1 − 0.85) = 5

LRs are independent of prevalence and can be compared across different diagnostic strategies.

(Choice A)  0.29 is the approximate LR− for a serum midkine level ≥320.5 pg/mL, calculated as (1 − sensitivity) / specificity = (1 − 0.75) / (0.85) ≈ 0.29.  However, the researchers want to report LR+, not LR−.

Educational objective:
The likelihood ratio is the probability of a patient with the disease having a particular finding (eg, positive or negative test result) divided by the probability of a patient without the disease having the same finding.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Likelihood Ratio

questionList.questionText: Consecutive readings of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure were obtained from a patient in the intensive care unit using a Swan-Ganz catheter.  The readings are 20 mm Hg, 22 mm Hg, 21 mm Hg, 22 mm Hg, and 18 mm Hg.  Which of the following is the median of the values given above?
questionList.explanationText:
It is important to know the difference between the measures of central tendency (mean, mode, and median).  The median of a dataset is the number that separates the right half from the left half of the dataset.  The dataset MUST be ordered before the median is determined.  In this case, the ordered dataset is {18, 20, 21, 22, 22}.  The value 21 splits the dataset in half (2 values to the left and 2 values to the right); therefore, it is the median.

If the number of observations is even, finding the median becomes trickier; it requires finding the middle 2 values, adding them together, and dividing the resulting sum by 2.  For example, if there were an additional measurement of 18 mm Hg, the ordered dataset would consist of 6 observations (even number): {18, 18, 20, 21, 22, 22}.  The median value splits the dataset in half; it lies between 20 and 21, with 3 values on the left ({18, 18, 20}) and 3 values on the right ({21, 22, 22}).  The median would be (20 + 21) / 2 = 20.5 mm Hg.

Another measure of the center of a dataset is the mode, which is the easiest value to find.  The mode is the most frequent value of a dataset.  In the scenario described, the mode is 22 mm Hg (Choice E).  Some datasets have >1 mode (if several values are present with the same frequency).

To find the mean (or mathematical average) of a dataset, the sum of all the observations is divided by the number of observations.  In this case, the mean is equal to (18 + 20 + 21 + 22 + 22) / 5 = 20.6 mm Hg (Choice C).

Educational objective:
The median is the value that is located in the middle of a dataset.  It divides the right half of the data from the left half.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Central tendency (mean, median, mode, outliers)

questionList.questionText: In clinical practice, the "CAGE" questionnaire is used to screen patients for alcohol use disorder (AUD).  When a patient replies with 2 out of 4 positive responses to the "CAGE" questions, the test is considered to be positive for AUD.  If this criterion is changed so that 3 out of 4 positive responses to the "CAGE" questions label the patient as having AUD, what is the effect on the sensitivity and specificity of this test?
questionList.explanationText:
The ability to correctly identify patients with disease as positive is the sensitivity of the test, calculated as the number of true positives (TP) divided by the total number of TP and false negatives (FN):

Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN).

The ability to correctly identify patients without disease as negative is the specificity of the test, calculated as the number of true negatives (TN) divided by the total number of TN and false positives (FP):

Specificity = TN / (TN + FP).

Raising the cut-off point of a test will increase its specificity and decrease its sensitivity.  In this particular vignette, increasing the number of questions for a patient to be labelled as having alcohol use disorder will result in fewer people being identified as such.  Consequently, FPs and TPs will decrease, while FNs and TNs will increase.

Educational objective:
Raising the cut-off point (eg, increasing the inclusion criteria) of a screening test results in an increase in specificity and decrease in sensitivity.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity, specificity, NPV, PPV

answerChoiceList.choice: Both sensitivity and specificity of the test will decrease
Both sensitivity and specificity of the test will increase
Sensitivity will decrease but specificity will increase
Sensitivity will increase but specificity will decrease
Both sensitivity and specificity will remain the same

questionList.questionText:
A study is undertaken to evaluate a new serological screening test for the diagnosis of tuberculosis infection.  In the study, 1000 people were randomly selected from the population and given the new diagnostic test, and positive and negative results were recorded.  Each study participant also was given the gold standard diagnostic procedure to determine the true infection state of the individual.  The findings are as follows:

True Tuberculosis infection state
Test resultsYesNoTotal
Positive13060190
Negative50760810
Total1808201000

Which of the following is the positive predictive value of the screening test under study?
questionList.explanationText:
Although predictive values are not true indices of the validity of a test, these are still of prime importance to physicians.  In clinical practice, patients will more often present with a positive or negative test result, rather than a disease or disease-free state; therefore, one should have sufficient knowledge about the predictive values of a test.

Positive predictive value is defined as the proportion of subjects with a positive test result who actually have the disease.  Negative predictive value is defined as the proportion of subjects with a negative test result who are free of disease.  Consider the following 2 x 2 table:

Disease
Test resultsPresentAbsentTotal
PositiveA
True positive (TP)		B
False positive (FP)		A+B
NegativeC
False Negative (FN)		D
True Negative (TN)		C+D
TotalA+CB+DA+B+C+D
Positive predictive value = TP/(TP+FP) or A/(A+B)
Negative predictive value = TN/(TN+FN) or D/(C+D)
In this case, the PPV is 130 / 190.

(Choice A)  Sensitivity and specificity are useful for assessing the validity of a test.  130/180 is the sensitivity of the test.

(Choice D)  760/810 is the negative predictive value of the test.

Educational objective:
Know how to calculate the predictive values of a test.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity, specificity, NPV, PPV

questionList.questionText:
A randomized controlled trial was conducted to investigate the effect of intravenous lidocaine on hemodynamic response to endotracheal intubation during induction of anesthesia using a novel, strong opioid.  Ninety patients age 18-65 were recruited.  Induction of anesthesia was initiated using a standard protocol.  The patients were then randomized to 3 groups: Group L1 received 1 mg kg−1 of lidocaine, Group L1.5 received 1.5 mg kg−1 of lidocaine, and Group S received a standardized volume of normal saline.  Baseline analysis compared the distributions of sex, age, and body mass among treatment groups.  The plots below show the distribution of body mass in each treatment group.

An analysis of variance (ANOVA) was conducted to compare mean body mass among groups and yielded a p-value of 0.022.  If a significance level of α = 0.01 is considered, which of the following statements is true?
questionList.explanationText:
This randomized controlled trial investigated the effect of intravenous lidocaine on hemodynamic response to endotracheal intubation during induction of anesthesia using a strong opioid.  Patients age 18-65 underwent induction of anesthesia and were then randomized to 3 groups: Group L1 (1 mg kg−1 of lidocaine), Group L1.5 (1.5 mg kg−1 of lidocaine), and Group S (normal saline).  Baseline analysis compared the distributions of sex, age, and body mass among treatment groups.  The plots show the distribution of body mass in each treatment group (ie, L1, L1.5, S).

When conditions for statistical inference are met, a suitable statistical test to compare the means of a quantitative variable (eg, body mass in kilograms) among ≥2 independent groups (ie, treatment groups) is the analysis of variance (ANOVA), which determines whether at least 1 group mean differs from the other group means (Choice A).

In hypothesis testing, the p-value is compared to a significance level α (eg, 0.05, 0.01) to determine whether there is sufficient statistical evidence against a null hypothesis H0 and in favor of an alternative Ha (Choice F).  The null H0 and alternative Ha hypotheses for ANOVA are as follows:

  • H0:  The means of a quantitative variable are not different among groups.

  • Ha:  At least 1 group mean is different from the other group means.

One interpretation of the p-value is as follows:
