  • If p-value ≥ significance level α, there is no significant difference in group means (data do not provide statistical evidence that Ha is true).

  • If p-value < significance level α, there is a significant difference in at least 1 group mean (data provide statistical evidence that Ha is true).

In this study, the significance level α is 0.01, and the ANOVA yielded a p-value of 0.022 (which is > 0.01); therefore, there is no significant difference in mean body mass among groups because p-value > α (Choices B, C, and D).  This indicates that there is not sufficient evidence to reject H0.

Educational objective:
Analysis of variance (ANOVA) compares the means of independent groups and determines whether at least 1 group mean differs from the others.  A p-value ≥ significance level α indicates that results are not statistically significant (eg, there is no statistical evidence of a difference), and vice versa.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Statistical tests

answerChoiceList.choice: Differences in mean body mass among groups cannot be assessed using ANOVA
There is a significant difference in mean body mass among groups because p-value < α
There is a significant difference in mean body mass among groups because p-value > α
There is no significant difference in mean body mass among groups because p-value < α
There is no significant difference in mean body mass among groups because p-value > α
There is not enough information to determine whether there is a significant difference in mean body mass among groups

questionList.questionText: Medical students are planning a case-control study to examine the association between intrapartum antibiotic (IPA) exposure and late-onset serious bacterial infection (SBI) in full-term infants.  A random sample of healthy full-term infants born via vaginal or cesarean delivery who were hospitalized for late-onset SBI at age 7-90 days will be selected from the pediatric clinic's medical records.  A sample of healthy, age- and sex-matched, full-term infants who are known not to have had SBI will also be selected from the pediatric clinic.  Both vaginal deliveries, which do not routinely include antibiotic prophylaxis, and cesarean deliveries, which routinely include antibiotic prophylaxis, will be included in the study.  IPA exposure will be defined as any maternal antibiotic use in the 24 hours prior to delivery.  Previous research has shown that risk of neonatal infection, including late-onset SBI, is increased with prematurity, history of maternally transmitted infection, cesarean delivery, and comorbidities.  Which of the following sources of bias is of greatest potential concern in this study?
questionList.explanationText:
Confounding bias occurs when a study does not control for extraneous (ie, confounding) variables independently associated with both the risk factor (ie, independent variable) and the outcome (ie, dependent variable).  When not controlled, confounders may mask the true effect that the independent variable has on the dependent variable, which may lead to false conclusions about their association (ie, statistically significant associations that are truly invalid).

In this question, medical students are planning a case-control study examining the association of intrapartum antibiotic (IPA) exposure and late-onset serious bacterial infection (SBI) in infants.  They intend to include both vaginal and cesarean deliveries.  Cesarean deliveries are associated with both IPA exposure (given that they require antibiotic prophylaxis) and late-onset SBI (given that they are associated with increased risk of neonatal infection).  Therefore, including cesarean deliveries in the study will potentially distort (ie, mask) the true association between IPA and SBI.  This is an example of confounding bias.

(Choice A)  Attrition bias refers to an unequal loss of participants from study groups in follow-up (eg, cohort, experimental) studies.  This study has a case-control design, which does not include a follow-up period.

(Choice C)  Misclassification bias occurs when errors in the identification of exposure status (eg, received vs did not receive IPA) or disease status (eg, developed vs did not develop SBI) do not occur to the same degree between study groups.  In this study, both exposure (ie, IPA) and disease (ie, SBI) will be assessed through medical records, so it is very unlikely that either exposure or disease status will be misclassified.

(Choice D)  Recall bias refers to the inaccurate recollection of past exposure or outcome status.  It is a potential problem for case-control studies, particularly when questionnaires are used to ask participants about distant past exposure.  In this study, exposure and outcome will be assessed through medical records, so recall bias is very unlikely.

(Choice E)  Selection bias occurs due to inadequate (eg, nonrandom) sample selection methods, and it yields study samples that are not representative of the target populations.  This study design minimizes selection bias by randomly selecting cases from the pediatric clinic and using infants from the same clinic who have been matched by age and sex to these randomly selected cases.  Confounding bias is of much greater concern.

Educational objective:
Confounding bias occurs when an extraneous (ie, confounding) variable masks the association between an independent variable (eg, risk factor, treatment) and a dependent variable (ie, outcome, disease of interest).  It may lead to false conclusions about the association (ie, statistically significant associations that are truly invalid).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Bias

questionList.questionText: A study is conducted to determine the mean level of total serum cholesterol in patients with acute coronary syndrome.  A total of 2,500 randomly selected patients participated in the study.  One of the study goals is to compare the mean level of total serum cholesterol between male and female patients with acute coronary syndrome.  Results showed that the mean total cholesterol level was 230 mg/dL for males and 220 mg/dL for females.  Which of the following is an appropriate statistical test to determine whether there is a difference in the mean cholesterol level between male and female patients with acute coronary syndrome?
questionList.explanationText:
Dependent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Quantitative

Independent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Chi-square, logistic regression*

t test, ANOVA, linear regression

Quantitative

Logistic regression*

Correlation, linear regression

*Dependent variable must be dichotomous.

ANOVA =  analysis of variance.

Variables are broadly classified as qualitative (ie, categorical) or quantitative (ie, continuous) based on their scale of measurement.  Qualitative variables (eg, type of treatment, blood type) represent categories or groups whereas quantitative variables (eg, temperature, glucose level) represent numerical values.  The scale of measurement of the dependent (eg, outcome) and independent (eg, exposure, characteristic of interest) variables in a study determines the correct statistical test for any given situation.

A two-sample t-test compares the mean of 2 independent groups.  It requires that a quantitative dependent variable (ie, outcome) be evaluated in 2 groups formed by the 2 levels of a categorical independent variable (ie, exposure, characteristic of interest).

In this study:

  • The quantitative dependent variable was level of total serum cholesterol.

  • The categorical independent variable was sex (male and female patients).

A two-sample t-test will determine whether there is a statistically significant difference in mean level of total serum cholesterol between male and female patients with acute coronary syndrome.  A large, statistically significant difference in these mean values indicates that male and female patients with acute coronary syndrome may have different cholesterol profiles (ie, the null hypothesis is rejected).

(Choice A)  The chi-square test evaluates the association between 2 categorical variables, as in a study evaluating the association between sex (ie, male and female) and myocardial infarction (ie, presence or absence).

(Choice B)  A correlation analysis uses the correlation coefficient to describe the linear relationship between 2 quantitative variables, as in a study evaluating the linear relationship between stress level and irritability score.

(Choice C)  A logistic regression analysis evaluates the association between 1 categorical dependent variable and ≥1 independent variables that may be quantitative or categorical, as in a study evaluating the association between age and myocardial infarction (ie, presence or absence).

(Choice D)  Meta-analysis is a quantitative statistical technique used to combine and analyze data from several studies to conduct an analysis with a greater statistical power than that of individual studies.

Educational objective:
The two-sample t-test compares the mean of 2 independent groups.  The test requires that a quantitative dependent variable (eg, outcome) be evaluated in 2 groups.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Statistical tests

questionList.questionText: A group of investigators plans to conduct a study to assess the relationship between colon cancer and elevated plasma C-reactive protein (CRP) levels.  The study design involves determining the prevalence of elevated plasma CRP levels (based on prespecified cutoff values) and of colon cancer in a sample of individuals at a given point in time.  The prevalence of elevated CRP levels is compared between patients with and without colon cancer.  Which of the following is the best statement of the null hypothesis for this study?
questionList.explanationText:
To state the null hypothesis correctly, the study design must be considered.  In this case, the study is cross-sectional as the investigators are taking a snapshot of a sample and measuring prevalence of elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) levels and of colon cancer at the same time.  Therefore, the null hypothesis should state that there is no association between elevated plasma CRP levels (equivalent to exposure) and colon cancer (equivalent to outcome).  In general, the null hypothesis represents a statement of no association between variables of interest.

As this is a cross-sectional study, the temporal relationship between the 2 variables (ie, whether the exposure preceded the outcome, or whether the outcome preceded the exposure) cannot be determined.  It would not be suitable for the null hypothesis in this case to suggest a temporality or risk profile, whether having colon cancer is a risk factor impacting CRP levels (Choice B) or having elevated CRP levels is a risk factor for colon cancer (Choice C).

(Choice A)  This would not be a suitable null hypothesis as it states that there is an association ("more prevalent") between an exposure and outcome.

(Choice D)  This would have been a valid statement of the null hypothesis for a cohort study, in which individuals with and without elevated CRP levels are followed over time to determine the risk of colon cancer.

Educational objective:
The null hypothesis is the statement of no relationship between the exposure and the outcome.  To state the null hypothesis correctly, the study design should be considered.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hypothesis testing

answerChoiceList.choice: Colon cancer is more prevalent among subjects with elevated CRP levels
Having a diagnosis of colon cancer does not affect plasma CRP levels
Subjects with elevated plasma CRP levels are prone to colon cancer
The risk of colon cancer is the same for subjects with and without elevated plasma CRP levels
There is no association between elevated plasma CRP level and colon cancer

questionList.questionText: Two new diagnostic tests (Test A and Test B) for Lyme disease were developed by a pharmaceutical company and their performance compared using a single population.  The company reported that a greater proportion of patients with Lyme disease tested positive with Test A than with Test B, but that a lower proportion of patients without Lyme disease tested negative with Test A than with Test B.  Based on this information, which of the following conclusions about the diagnostic tests must be true?
questionList.explanationText:
Positive condition

Negative condition

Positive test result

TP

FP

PPV =
TP / (TP + FP)

Negative test result

FN

TN

NPV =
TN / (TN + FN)

Sensitivity =

TP / (TP + FN)

Specificity =

TN / (TN + FP)

FN = false negative; FP = false positive; NPV = negative predictive value; PPV = positive predictive value; TN = true negative; TP = true positive.

In this example, the performance of 2 different diagnostic tests (Test A and Test B) for Lyme disease are compared in a single population.

  • The proportion of patients with disease who test positive is the sensitivity of the test, calculated as the number of true positives (TP) divided by the total number of TP and false negatives (FN): sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN).

  • The false negative rate (FNR) is the complement of the sensitivity (1 − sensitivity) and indicates the rate of negative test results among patients with disease.  A test with high sensitivity (ie, correctly identifying patients with disease as positive) has a low FNR (ie, low rate of negative results among patients with disease).

  • The proportion of patients without disease who test negative is the specificity of the test, calculated as the number of true negatives (TN) divided by the total number of TN and false positives (FP): specificity = TN / (TN + FP).

  • The false positive rate (FPR) is the complement of the specificity (1 − specificity) and indicates the rate of positive test results among patients without disease.  A test with high specificity has a low FPR.

The results showed that a greater proportion of patients with Lyme disease tested positive with Test A than with Test B.  This means that Test A is more sensitive than Test B; consequently, it also has a lower FNR.  In addition, results showed that a lower proportion of patients without Lyme disease tested negative with Test A than with Test B.  This means that Test A is less specific than Test B and consequently has a higher FPR (Choices D and E).

(Choices A and B)  The accuracy of a diagnostic test is the probability that a patient is correctly classified by the test and is calculated as: accuracy = (TP + TN) / (TP + TN + FP + FN).  The positive predictive value (PPV) of a diagnostic test is the probability that a positive test result correctly identifies patients with disease and is calculated as: PPV = TP / (TP + FP).  No information is given about the size of the samples studied or the exact sensitivity and specificity values; therefore, it is not possible to draw conclusions about the accuracy or PPV of the tests.

Educational objective:
More sensitive diagnostic tests have lower false negative rates than less sensitive tests.  More specific diagnostic tests have lower false positive rates than less specific tests.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity and specificity

answerChoiceList.choice: Test A has a higher accuracy than Test B
Test A has a higher positive predictive value than Test B
Test A has a higher false positive rate than Test B
Test A has a higher specificity than Test B
There is not enough information to draw a conclusion

questionList.questionText: A cohort study was conducted to determine whether there is an association between hysterectomy and hyperlipidemia.  Researchers selected 5,900 women who underwent hysterectomy in the past 6 months and 18,500 age-matched women who underwent surgery other than hysterectomy in the past 6 months.  At the end of a 5-year follow-up period, both groups were assessed for hyperlipidemia using standard laboratory criteria.  The results of the study showed a statistically significant association between hysterectomy and hyperlipidemia after adjusting for several known potential confounding factors.  The study concluded that women who undergo hysterectomy should routinely monitor their metabolic status.  Which of the following statements is true about this study design?
questionList.explanationText:
In a cohort study, participants are initially identified as being exposed or nonexposed according to their exposure to a risk factor (eg, hysterectomy).  Because participants are categorized based on their status with regard to a particular risk factor, a cohort study typically considers a single risk factor (ie, hysterectomy) per study.

Once participants are categorized based on exposure status, the incidence of ≥1 outcomes of interest (eg, hyperlipidemia) within a specific period (ie, 5 years) is determined and compared between the exposed and nonexposed groups to estimate the association between risk factor and outcome.  Because cohort studies measure incidence of disease, they provide a measure of risk of disease.

(Choice A)  Intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis is a method for analyzing results in a randomized trial where all participants who are randomized are included in the analysis and analyzed according to the group they were originally randomized to, regardless of what treatment they received.  However, this study is a cohort (ie, observational) study; therefore, participants were not randomized into treatments.

(Choice C)  Outcome misclassification occurs when the outcome under investigation is not identified correctly.  In this study, it is very unlikely that the outcome (hyperlipidemia) was misclassified given the use of standard laboratory criteria.

(Choice D)  Inaccurate recollection of past events, known as recall bias, is a potential problem for case-control studies (not cohort studies), particularly when questionnaires are used to ask participants about distant past exposure.

Educational objective:
A cohort study begins by identifying individuals as exposed or nonexposed to a single risk factor and ends by comparing the incidence of ≥1 outcomes (ie, disease) between the 2 groups.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Study designs

answerChoiceList.choice: It could be analyzed using an intention-to-treat method
It is able to provide a measure of risk of disease
It may be affected by outcome misclassification
It may be affected by recall bias

questionList.questionText: A pharmaceutical company studied the efficacy of a new glucose-lowering monotherapy drug for patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).  Patients with recently diagnosed T2DM were randomly assigned to receive monotherapy with either the new drug or metformin for 6 months.  The primary outcome was the difference in mean glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels at 6 months.  Mean baseline HbA1c levels were similar between the 2 groups.  Although both groups showed significant reductions in HbA1c levels at 6 months, the reductions were larger in the new drug group than in the metformin group (−1.2% vs −0.7%; p = 0.02).  Which of the following best describes the meaning of the p-value?
questionList.explanationText:
Research studies generally compare a null hypothesis (H0) (eg, no difference between 2 group means) and an alternative hypothesis (Ha) (eg, difference between 2 group means).  One interpretation of the p-value is that it reflects the probability of obtaining results (eg, difference between 2 group means) that are as extreme or more extreme than (eg, greater than) the observed results when H0 is true.  A p-value can be calculated for every hypothesis test; the lower the p-value, the greater the evidence against a H0.

This study compared mean glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels between patients who received a new glucose-lowering monotherapy drug and patients who received metformin.  Therefore, the H0 in this study is that there is no real difference in mean HbA1c levels between the 2 treatment groups.  Study results showed reductions in HbA1c levels of −1.2% in the new drug group and −0.7% in the metformin group for a difference between groups of (−0.7%) – (−1.2%) = 0.5%.  The hypothesis test to compare the 2 group means had a p-value of 0.02.  Therefore, the interpretation of the p-value is as follows: If there is no real difference between treatments, there is a 2% chance of finding a mean HbA1c difference between groups of ≥0.5%.

(Choices A, C, D, and E)  The p-value is neither the proportion of patients with a certain outcome nor the probability that results have a specific value (eg, reduction in HbA1c levels of −1.2%).  The p-value is the probability of obtaining at least the observed results (eg, mean HbA1c difference between groups of ≥0.5%) when H0 is true (ie, there is no real difference in mean HbA1c levels between the 2 treatment groups).

Educational objective:
The p-value is the probability of obtaining results (eg, difference between 2 group means) that are as extreme or more extreme than (eg, greater than) the observed results when the null hypothesis H0 is true.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: P-value and confidence interval

answerChoiceList.choice: About 2% of patients treated with the new glucose-lowering monotherapy drug had lower HbA1c levels than patients treated with metformin
If there is no real difference between treatments, there is a 2% chance of finding a mean HbA1c level difference between groups of ≥0.5%
The difference in mean HbA1c levels between treatment groups will be ≤0.5% about 2% of the time
The new glucose-lowering monotherapy drug was effective in lowering HbA1c levels in 98% of patients who received it
There is a 2% chance that the new glucose-lowering monotherapy drug will reduce HbA1c levels by ≥1.2%

questionList.questionText: A clinical research center conducted a study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a topical quick-penetrating solution (QPS) of heparin compared to heparin topical gel in the prevention of infusion-associated phlebitis.  Two hundred patients undergoing intravenous cannulation for at least 72 hours were enrolled and randomized to receive 6-8 drops of QPS of heparin or 1 g of heparin sodium topical gel over the cannulated vein every 8 hours for a total of 10 doses.  After 72 hours, results show that the incidence of phlebitis is 60% in the QPS group and 75% in the gel group.  The reduction in incidence is statistically significant.  Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of these results?
questionList.explanationText:
Common measures of therapeutic efficacy

Term

Definition

Calculation

Absolute risk reduction (ARR)

Percentage indicating the actual difference in event rate between control & treatment groups

ARR = control rate – treatment rate

Relative risk reduction (RRR)

Percentage indicating relative reduction in the treatment event rate compared to the control group

RRR = ARR / control rate

Relative risk (RR)

Ratio of the probability of an event occurring in the treatment group compared to the control group

RR = treatment rate / control rate

Number needed to treat (NNT)

Number of individuals who need to be treated to prevent a negative outcome in 1 patient

NNT = 1 / ARR

The number needed to treat (NNT) is the number of patients who need to be treated with a specific drug (eg, quick-penetrating solution [QPS] of heparin) to prevent an additional negative event (eg, 1 fewer patient who develops phlebitis within 72 hours of intravenous cannulation) when compared with a control group (eg, heparin sodium topical gel).  NNT is the inverse of the absolute risk reduction (ARR):

NNT = 1 / ARR

The ARR describes the difference in risk (or rate) of an unfavorable event (eg, development of phlebitis within 72 hours of intravenous cannulation) between the treatment group (eg, heparin QPS) and the control group (eg, heparin gel):

ARR = (Riskcontrol − Risktreatment)

In this question, the incidence (ie, risk) of phlebitis within 72 hours of intravenous cannulation in the control group Riskcontrol is 75% (or 0.75) and in the treatment group Risktreatment is 60% (or 0.60).  Therefore, the ARR for development of phlebitis within 72 hours of intravenous cannulation in the treatment group is:

ARR = (Riskcontrol − Risktreatment) = (0.75 − 0.60) = 0.15 (Choices A and B)

and the NNT is:

NNT = 1 / ARR = 1 / 0.15 = 6.7 ≈ 7 (Choice C)

NNTs are always rounded up to the nearest whole number, so approximately 7 patients need to be treated with heparin QPS to prevent 1 additional case of phlebitis within 72 hours of intravenous cannulation.  Alternatively, this indicates that for every 7 patients treated with heparin QPS instead of heparin gel, 1 additional case of phlebitis is prevented.

(Choices E and F)  The relative risk reduction (RRR) describes the relative decrease in the risk of an adverse event in the treatment group compared to a control group; it is calculated as: RRR = [(Riskcontrol − Risktreatment) / Riskcontrol] = (0.75 − 0.60) / 0.75 = 0.20 (or 20%).

Educational objective:
The number needed to treat (NNT) is the number of patients who need to receive a treatment to prevent 1 additional negative event.  NNT is the inverse of the absolute risk reduction.  The lower the NNT, the more effective the treatment because fewer patients need be treated to prevent 1 additional negative event.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Number Needed To Treat

questionList.questionText: A researcher wants to conduct a case-control study to evaluate the association between the use of antihyperglycemic drugs and dementia in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).  The proposed study will include a review of medical charts at a large local diabetes clinic.  Cases will be identified as patients with T2DM who had been diagnosed with dementia in the last 5 years (index date).  Controls will be identified as patients with T2DM without dementia matched to cases by age, sex, and index date.  Data on participants' use of antihyperglycemic drugs prior to the index date will also be collected from medical charts.  Based on the study design, which of the following is correct about institutional review board (IRB) approval for the study?
questionList.explanationText:
An institutional review board (IRB) is a committee with the authority to review, approve, disapprove, or require modifications in research activities involving human participants.  The primary objective of any IRB is to protect the rights and welfare of human subjects involved in research; IRB review ensures that research with human subjects is conducted in accordance with all federal, institutional, and ethical guidelines.

According to federal regulations, all research studies involving human participants must be submitted to an IRB for approval before study initiation, regardless of study design (eg, observational, secondary data analysis, no interaction with patients) (Choices B, C, D, and E).  Therefore, this case-control study will require IRB approval.

Educational objective:
All research studies involving human participants, regardless of study design (eg, observational, secondary data analysis, no interaction with patients), must be submitted to an institutional review board for approval before study initiation.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Research ethics

answerChoiceList.choice: IRB approval will not be required because the study is observational
IRB approval will not be required because the study will not involve interaction with patients
IRB approval will not be required because the study will use only secondary data
There is not enough information to determine whether IRB approval will be required

questionList.questionText: A group of physicians wants to determine the relationship between metabolic abnormalities and moyamoya disease (MMD), a chronic cerebrovascular occlusion disorder that may lead to ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke.  Prior data suggested that serum uric acid and triglycerides may both be associated with vasoocclusion.  The physicians therefore design a study to investigate whether, in individuals newly diagnosed with MMD, serum uric acid levels are independently related to serum triglyceride levels after adjusting for sociodemographic characteristics, BMI, smoking status, and alcohol consumption.  Three hundred individuals are recruited, and quantitative levels of serum uric acid and triglycerides are measured at baseline.  Which of the following is the best statistical technique to answer the research question?
questionList.explanationText:
Dependent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Quantitative

Independent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Chi-square, logistic regression*

t test, ANOVA, linear regression

Quantitative

Logistic regression*

Correlation, linear regression

*Dependent variable must be dichotomous.

ANOVA =  analysis of variance.

Variables are broadly classified as qualitative (ie, categorical) or quantitative (eg, continuous) based on their scale of measurement.  Qualitative variables (eg, type of treatment, blood type) represent categories or groups, whereas quantitative variables (eg, temperature, glucose level) represent numerical values.  The scale of measurement of the dependent (eg, outcome) and independent (eg, exposures, risk factors) variables in a study determines the correct statistical test.

Regression analysis is used to describe the association between 1 quantitative dependent variable (eg, outcome) and ≥1 independent variables (eg, exposures, risk factors), which may be quantitative or qualitative, while adjusting for other variables of interest.  In this study:

  • The 1 quantitative dependent variable is serum triglyceride level.

  • The independent variable is serum uric acid level (1 quantitative independent variable).

  • The association between the main independent variable (eg, serum uric acid) and the dependent variable (eg, serum triglyceride) is adjusted to account for the effects of other independent variables referred to as adjustment variables or covariates (eg, sociodemographic characteristics, BMI, smoking status, alcohol consumption).  Controlling for these variables reduces potential confounding.

Calculation of a regression line (eg, line of best fit) can then determine whether serum uric acid level has a statistically significant association with serum triglyceride level (after adjusting for covariates).  In this study, uric acid level is considered the independent variable (ie, independently related to triglyceride level); however, an equivalent relationship could have been studied using triglyceride level as the independent variable.  In both instances, the best statistical technique is linear regression.

(Choice A)  The analysis of variance (ANOVA) compares the mean of a quantitative dependent variable in several independent groups.  For example, ANOVA could be used to compare mean serum triglyceride level in patients with low, normal, or high serum uric acid levels (3 groups).

(Choices C and D)  Odds ratio (OR) and relative risk (RR) measure the strength of association between 2 categorical variables: a categorical risk factor (eg, smoker or nonsmoker) and a categorical outcome or disease (eg, presence or absence of myocardial infarction).  The OR is used in case-control studies, and the RR is used in cohort studies.

Educational objective:
A regression analysis is a statistical technique used to describe the effect of ≥1 independent variables (eg, exposures, risk factors), which may be quantitative or qualitative, on 1 quantitative dependent variable (ie, outcome).

questionList.questionText: A large pediatric group practice has experienced a noticeable increase in the number of high school students seeking care for anxiety.  The group decides to use a new screening tool for anxiety in teenagers that was reported to be 86% sensitive and 78% specific on a sample of 400 high school students, of whom 25% were known to have anxiety.  Which of the following is the approximate probability that a high school student in this sample with a negative test result does not have the condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Positive condition

Negative condition

Positive test result

TP

FP

PPV =
TP / (TP + FP)

Negative test result

FN

TN

NPV =
TN / (TN + FN)

Sensitivity =

TP / (TP + FN)

Specificity =

TN / (TN + FP)

FN = false negative; FP = false positive; NPV = negative predictive value; PPV = positive predictive value; TN = true negative; TP = true positive.

Negative predictive value (NPV) is the probability that an individual truly does not have the disease given a negative test result.  It is equal to the number of individuals who do not have the disease and who have a negative test result (ie, true negative [TN]) divided by the total number of individuals with a negative test result (ie, TN + false negative [FN]):

NPV = TN / (TN + FN)

In this case, TN and FN can be determined by constructing a 2 × 2 table based on the given prevalence, sensitivity, and specificity.

  • The prevalence of anxiety in the sample of 400 students is 25%; therefore, 400 × 0.25 = 100 students have anxiety, and 400 − 100 = 300 do not have anxiety.

  • The reported sensitivity of the tool (ie, probability of a patient with the disease testing positive) is 86%, so 100 × 0.86 = 86 of 100 students with anxiety will test positive (ie, true positive [TP]), and 100 − 86 = 14 will test negative (ie, FN).

  • The reported specificity of the tool (ie, probability of a patient without the disease testing negative) is 78%, so 300 × 0.78 = 234 students without anxiety will test negative (ie, TN), and 300 − 234 = 66 will test positive (ie, false positive [FP]).

Then the NPV can be calculated by NPV = TN / (TN + FN).  In this case:

NPV = 234 / (234 + 14) = (234 / 248) = ~0.94

Therefore, the probability of a high school student with a negative test result not having the condition is approximately 94%.

(Choice A)  0.18 is the negative likelihood ratio (LR−).  It is calculated as the probability of a patient with the disease testing negative divided by the probability of a patient without the disease testing negative, which is equal to (1 − sensitivity) / specificity.

(Choice B)  0.57 is the positive predictive value (PPV).  It is calculated as TP / (TP + FP) and represents the probability that an individual truly has the disease given a positive test result.

(Choice C)  0.62 is the overall proportion of negative tests in the sample.  It is calculated as (FN + TN) / (TP + FP + TN + FN).

(Choice D)  0.80 is the overall accuracy of the test in the sample.  It is calculated as (TP + TN) / (TP + FP + TN + FN) and represents the probability that an individual will be correctly classified by a test.

Educational objective:
Negative predictive value (NPV) is the probability that an individual does not have a disease given a negative test result.  It is calculated as NPV = true negative / (true negative + false negative).

questionList.title: Sensitivity, specificity, NPV, PPV

questionList.questionText: A 40-year-old woman presents to the office with several months history of atypical chest pain.  Her family history is positive for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus.  Her past medical history is insignificant.  An ECG stress test is performed to evaluate the possibility of coronary heart disease.  This test has 85% sensitivity and 80% specificity.  In the low-risk group, its positive predictive value is 25%, and negative predictive value is 96%.  If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient has coronary heart disease?
questionList.explanationText:
Pre- and post-test probabilities, as well as positive and negative predictive values, are very important concepts in clinical medicine, as they dramatically change the approach to the diagnosis of each disease.  Take the time to learn and fully understand these terms.

The pre-test probability sets your expectations before performing the diagnostic test.  It describes the existing probability of a patient to have the disease in question even before using a particular diagnostic test.  (Although there is a mathematical approach to calculate the pre-test probability, we shall simplify this term and use the most basic explanations.)  Using the example given above, the pre-test probability of the patient having coronary artery disease can be assumed to be low since she has no risk factors aside from her significant family history, and since she has atypical chest pain.  Statistically, the prevalence is directly related to the pre-test probability.  In this example, the patient belongs to the low-risk group, which consistently has a relatively low prevalence of coronary artery disease.

The positive predictive value (PPV) describes the probability of having the disease if the test result is positive.  The post-test probability of having the disease is directly related to the PPV.  Using the example above, the PPV (25%) is low.  Consequently, if the test result is positive, then the post-test probability of having the disease is low.  The post-test probability is also dependent on the sensitivity, specificity, and pre-test probability of having the disease.

The negative predictive value (NPV) describes the probability of not having the disease if the test result is negative.  In this example, the NPV is 96%.  This means that if the test result is negative, the chances of the patient to not have the disease is high (96%).  Conversely, if the test result is negative, the chances of the patient to have the disease is low (100% - 96%= 4%).

Other cases and diagnostic tests which are high-yield for the USMLE are listed below:

  1. Pulmonary embolism and perfusion-ventilation scanning
  2. Prostate cancer and serum PSA levels

(Choice B)  False positive ratio = 1- specificity.

(Choice C)  False negative ratio = 1 - sensitivity.

Educational Objective:
If a test result is negative, the probability of having the disease is 1 - negative predictive value.

questionList.questionText:
A group of interventional cardiologists conducted a randomized controlled trial to determine whether telemonitoring has an effect on heart failure outcomes among patients recently hospitalized for heart failure.  A sample of 1,653 patients hospitalized for heart failure in the previous 30 days was randomly assigned to receive usual care or undergo telemonitoring, according to a sequence of computer-generated random numbers.  The primary end point was a composite of readmission for any reason or death from any cause within 180 days after enrollment.  A committee of physicians, all unaware of the treatment-group assignments, adjudicated each potential readmission to ensure that the event qualified as a readmission (and not another clinical encounter such as an emergency department visit) and to determine the primary cause of the readmission.  An excerpt of the study results is shown below.

End Point

(n = 826)

Usual Care
(n = 827)

Primary end point: death or readmission
   — no. (%)

432 (52.3)

Which of the following statistical tests is adequate to determine whether telemonitoring affects heart failure outcomes among patients recently hospitalized for heart failure?
questionList.explanationText:
Dependent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Quantitative

Independent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Chi-square, logistic regression*

t test, ANOVA, linear regression

Quantitative

Logistic regression*

Correlation, linear regression

*Dependent variable must be dichotomous.

ANOVA =  analysis of variance.

Variables are broadly classified as qualitative (ie, categorical) or quantitative (ie, continuous) based on the scale of measurement.  Qualitative variables (eg, type of treatment, blood type) represent categories or groups, whereas quantitative variables (eg, temperature, glucose level) represent numerical values.  The scale of measurement of the dependent (eg, outcome) and independent (eg, exposure, risk factor) variables in a study determines the correct statistical test for any given situation.

A chi-square test evaluates the relationship between 2 categorical variables.  It requires a categorical independent variable (eg, exposure or intervention) that is used to divide study participants into 2 groups and a categorical dependent variable (eg, outcome).  The test is used when 2 groups are independent (ie, when observations in a sample are unrelated to observations in another sample).  In this study:

  • The categorical dependent variable is the composite primary end point of readmission or death from any cause (with categories "readmission or death" and "no readmission or death").

  • The categorical independent variable is type of care (with categories "telemonitoring" and "usual care").

A chi-square test will determine whether there is a statistically significant relationship (association) between groups.  A statistically significant test indicates that type of care is associated with (ie, has an effect on) heart failure outcomes.

(Choice A)  The analysis of variance (ANOVA) test compares the mean of a quantitative variable of ≥3 independent groups, as in a study comparing serum ferritin concentrations (ie, quantitative variable) in children (age 0-12), adolescents (age 13-17), adults (age 18-59), and seniors (age ≥60).

(Choice C)  A correlation analysis uses the correlation coefficient to describe the linear relationship between 2 quantitative variables, as in a study evaluating the linear relationship between stress level and irritability score.

(Choice D)  Meta-analysis is a quantitative statistical technique used to combine and analyze data from several studies to conduct an analysis with a greater statistical power than that of the individual studies.

(Choice E)  Two-sample t-test compares the mean of a quantitative variable of 2 independent groups, as in a study comparing serum ferritin concentrations (ie, quantitative variable) in male and female patients.

Educational objective:
A chi-square test evaluates the relationship between 2 categorical variables.  It requires a categorical independent variable (eg, exposure or intervention) that is used to divide study participants into 2 groups and a categorical dependent variable (eg, outcome).

questionList.questionText:
A group of scientists developed a new qualitative test to diagnose fibromyalgia.  They conducted a study to evaluate the performance of the test in a sample of 2,500 subjects where 5% had a confirmed diagnosis of fibromyalgia.  The initial results of the study are shown below.

Fibromyalgia
YesNo
Test resultPositive100285
Negative252,090

Which of the following would result in an increase of the ratio of true positives to all positive tests?
questionList.explanationText:
Positive condition

Negative condition

Positive test result

TP

FP

PPV =
TP / (TP + FP)

Negative test result

FN

TN

NPV =
TN / (TN + FN)

Sensitivity =

TP / (TP + FN)

Specificity =

TN / (TN + FP)

FN = false negative; FP = false positive; NPV = negative predictive value; PPV = positive predictive value; TN = true negative; TP = true positive.

The positive predictive value (PPV) is the probability that an individual truly has a disease given a positive test result.  PPV is equal to the number of individuals with the disease who test positive (ie, true positive [TP]) divided by all those with a positive test result (ie, TP + false positive [FP]).  It is calculated as:

PPV = TP / (TP + FP)

Similarly, negative predictive value (NPV) is equal to the number of individuals without the disease who test negative (ie, true negative [TN]) divided by all those with a negative test result (ie, TN + false negative [FN]), calculated as: NPV = TN / (TN + FN).

Predictive values depend on disease prevalence in a population of interest.  Specifically, disease prevalence affects PPV by changing TP and FP.

  • Populations with low disease prevalence have more TN and fewer TP.  In such populations, more positive tests would have more FP with fewer FN.  This explains why NPV increases (ie, more TN, fewer FN) and PPV decreases (ie, fewer TP, more FP) with decreasing prevalence.

  • Populations with high disease prevalence have more TP and fewer TN.  In such populations, more negative tests would have more FN with fewer FP.  This explains why NPV decreases (ie, fewer TN, more FN) and PPV increases (ie, more TP, fewer FP) with increasing prevalence.

In this case, a new qualitative test to diagnose fibromyalgia is evaluated in a study sample of 2,500 subjects where 5% had a confirmed diagnosis of fibromyalgia.  This means that the test was evaluated in a study sample with a low prevalence of disease.  One way to increase the PPV of the test would be to evaluate the test in a sample from a population with a higher prevalence of disease (Choice D).  Therefore, testing a sample from a high-risk population would increase the ratio of true positives to all positive tests (PPV).

(Choices A and B)  Predictive values do not depend on the size of the study sample; instead, they depend on the prevalence of disease in the sample.

Educational objective:
Predictive values change depending on the disease prevalence in a study population.  As disease prevalence increases, the positive predictive value increases and the negative predictive value decreases, and vice versa.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity, specificity, NPV, PPV

answerChoiceList.choice: Increasing the sample size of the study
Reducing the sample size of the study
Testing a sample from a high-risk population
Testing a sample from a low-risk population
